Control Flow

Emojicode provides different types of control flow statements that allow you to structure the flow of the program.

ğŸ‡ğŸ‰ Code Block

Code blocks are used in conjunction with control flow structures to group statements that will be executed only under if a condition is met or not met or that will be repeated.

Syntactic definition:

block âŸ¶ ğŸ‡ statments ğŸ‰
statements âŸ¶ statement statements | statement

Examples of blocks can be seen below.

ğŸŠ If

The ğŸŠ statement is very important. It allows for conditional execution of a code block. The whole syntax is:

ğŸŠ condition block [else-ifs] [else]
else-ifs âŸ¶ else-if else-ifs | else-if
else-if âŸ¶ ğŸ‹ condition block
else âŸ¶ ğŸ“ block
condition âŸ¶ expression | frozen-declaration

If the condition evaluates to ğŸ‘, the code block will be executed, and if it evaluates to ğŸ‘ it'll be ignored.

This example will display a is bigger b if a is bigger b:

ğŸ¦ a 10
ğŸ¦ b 4
ğŸŠ â–¶ï¸ a b ğŸ‡
  ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¤a is bigger than bğŸ”¤
ğŸ‰

ğŸ“

ğŸ“ extends an ğŸŠ statement to execute an additional code block in case the expression in the if statement evaluates to false. For example, the following code would display a is greater than b if â€œa is greater than bâ€ and â€œa is not greater than bâ€ otherwise:

ğŸ¦ a 2
ğŸ¦ b 8
ğŸŠ â–¶ï¸ a b ğŸ‡
  ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¤a is bigger bğŸ”¤
ğŸ‰
ğŸ“ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¤a is not greater than bğŸ”¤
ğŸ‰

The ğŸ“ statements is only executed if the ğŸŠ statement evaluated to false, and if all ğŸ‹ statements evaluated to false too.

ğŸ‹

ğŸ‹ extends an ğŸŠ statement to execute different statements in case the original ğŸŠ condition evaluates to ğŸ‘. However, unlike ğŸŠ, it will execute that alternative expressions only if the ğŸŠ expression is ğŸ‘. For example, the following code would display â€œa is bigger than bâ€, â€œa equal to bâ€ or â€œa is smaller than bâ€:

ğŸ¦ a 2
ğŸ¦ b 7
ğŸŠ â–¶ï¸ a b ğŸ‡
  ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¤a is bigger than bğŸ”¤
ğŸ‰
ğŸ‹ ğŸ˜› a b ğŸ‡
  ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¤a equal to bğŸ”¤
ğŸ‰
ğŸ“ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¤a is smaller than bğŸ”¤
ğŸ‰

The ğŸ‹ statement is only executed if the preceding ğŸŠ expression and any preceding ğŸ‹ expressions evaluated to ğŸ‘, and the current ğŸ‹ expression evaluated to ğŸ‘.

ğŸ”‚ For In

The ğŸ”‚ statement allows you to quickly iterate over an instance, that is repeatedly retrieving values from it until there are no more values to provide. For example, you can iterate over an ğŸ¨ instance and youâ€™ll receive all elements contained in the list. The ğŸ”‚ statement can iterate over instances of any type which conforms to the ğŸ”‚ğŸšElement protocol.

Its syntax is:

ğŸ”‚ variable expression block

The compiler then transforms the statement into byte code equivalent to the statement rewritten to

ğŸ¦ iterator ğŸ¡iterable
ğŸ” â“ iterator ğŸ‡
  ğŸ¦ variable ğŸ”½ iterator
  ğŸ‘´ The provided block is executed here
ğŸ‰

where iteratable is the instance to iterate over (the result from evaluating the expression) and variable the variable name provided. Evidently, the variable will be of the type that was provided to the generic argument Element when the type of iterable declared its conformance to ğŸ”‚ğŸšElement.

Letâ€™s take a look at an example:

ğŸ¦ list ğŸ¨ğŸ”¤treeğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤beeğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤leeğŸ”¤ ğŸ”¤meğŸ”¤ğŸ†

ğŸ”‚ name list ğŸ‡
  ğŸ˜€ name
ğŸ‰

In this example, the code block will be repeated for every value of the list and the values tree, bee, lee, and me will be printed. The type of name is naturally ğŸ”¡. Thatâ€™s due to the fact that ğŸ¨ğŸšElement declared its conformance to ğŸ”‚ as ğŸ”‚ğŸšElement and therefore also returns an iterator of type ğŸ¡ğŸšElement from which the type of the variable is inferred.

Hint

If you need to repeat something for a given amount of times you should use â© Ranges in combination with ğŸ”‚.

ğŸ” Repeat While

ğŸ” repeats a given code block as long as condition is ğŸ‘. This also means that if the condition is never ğŸ‘ the code block will never be executed. The syntax is:

ğŸ” condition block

For example, this program will infinitely print â€œdisko disko partinzaniâ€.

ğŸ” ğŸ‘ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ˜€ ğŸ”¤disko disko partinzaniğŸ”¤
ğŸ‰

Due to the ease of use of the ğŸ”‚ statement ğŸ” is only used very seldom.
